author: A_Brickset_user
title: VADER! PALPATINE! HIS THRONE! ALL FOR 6 EUROS! (7. 27 DOLLARS) THANK YOU LEGO
review:
by tradition, i tend to write loooooooooooong reviews, and in denglish too (english spoken/written by a Dutchman, as I am, with things like 'recieve')
since i'm in a bit of a hurry today, i will rate this set as quick as possible.
all is great about this set, from the removable helmet of vader, to the scarred anakin face underneath it (shouldn't the anakin face be pale white like bib fortnuna's face is?), his body with the life support, the palpatine fig has a great body and detailed wrinkled face (should have been grey, but it's fine this way) vader comes with red saber, palpatine with his cane (which is just a black stick, not crooked like the real prop, but again, it's fine since it's just lego and lego has limits, it's not an action fig)
the throne with the death star II window is greeeeaaaaaaat no complaints at all (clever re-use of the tie window) the throne rotates!
there is only one flaw that really bugs me, there is no force lightning included. i guess lego just didn't had time or money to mould electric effects but if they had just included two transparent blue flames, i would have been totally happy and given this set a big 10! now it's fine too and gets a nine for 2 great figs and a backdrop accessory that's actually movie-accurate and compliments the figures, all great, lego did a phenomenal job!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: if you're looking for minifigs and windows...
review:
This might be a good set if you are looking for minifigs and for tie windows. Well there's not much to say about it. The throne is cool, but the reason why I bought it was to have vador. I like the fact that they didn't just put some black or yellow head under the mask as they do for troopers, you really get vadors face (end of ROTJ). And why complain about the mask, I think it looks good. you also get the emperor.

All in all a good cheap set!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Decent little set
review:
This set is one of two nearly economy-priced sets that give you the most dramatic moments of Return of the Jedi with a some minifigs. My only, only, gripe is that the original retail price was $10, so I didn't get any until TRU and KB put them on massive clearance for $5 each. 

Minifigs: They make up most of and carry this set. What you get is the Emperor sitting in his throne with the backdrop of a TIE windscreen for the big circular window. Works perfectly, and the throne is just plain elegant. 

Vader is an awesome fig. The helmet is detailed to a level worthy of an action figure, and the only innacuracy I can spot is that it's a bit wide from profile angle, but that's to accomodate the size of a lego head. Second of all, you can unmast him! and beneath his mask lies the scarred and saddened face of Anakin Skywalker, finally liberated from his mechanical prison. 

The Emperor fig's face is appropriately stylized and the fig comes complete with a black cloak and hood. I like to use this fig to customize generic dark Jedi. 

Overall, the set is great and an incredible buy when on clearance. 9 out of 10 for having a big original retail price.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Ok, but a bit pricey!
review: This set(if you can call it that) is great it you want a couple of hard to find minifigs. The building structure is simple but effective (I only got it because of the tie cockpit). £10 is very very expensive for what it is. You would be better off buting those 2003 Jabba palace sets (Jabbas prize & Jabbas message) as they are cheaper and have better pieces.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: The good seen for a cheap price!!!!
review: Star Wars episode VI, the Return of the Jedi. The dark room on the death star 2. I cant even believe it that Palpatine is in it but he looks good. Vader is good too. I would rather get him the xpensive way with the TIE Advanced but who gives a muck! The liittle structure the emporer sits on is cool and you can simulate the real seen easily in a dark room. I give it a 10 because it is small and when something is this small, not much can screw it up, other than how small it is, that is! You get the empires' best, Darth Vader with a real fig head and emporer palpatine. Plus, you can go pretty far with this set and if you get final dual 2, you can connect them and make a real walkway for luke, a stormtrooper, and an imperial commander. have fun with this little but good set! Chow Fa' Now!

author: A_Brickset_user
title: whats with that old fart sitting in the chair?
review:
its a good set with minifigs that arent half bad.  the emporer only comes with the 2 shuttles, but they cost too much.  also darth vader is someone who you dont find as often as you used to.  the detail for the chair is very cool with the buttons and overhead piece.




overall

decent

author: A_Brickset_user
title: shouldnt this one be called final duel 2 and the other final duel 1?
review: this set is sweet mainly cause vader is in it and he's awsome anyway the chair has great detail but the window is way to small you cant see anything out of that. combind this set with final duel 2 and you got one of the best scences in ROTJ.

author: _add_um
title: Simple but effective classic set.
review:
*Review revised on the 7th Janurary 2014*

Box/Instructions

The box of course in very small since it only contains 31 parts. Instructions are self explanatory and easy to follow. I like the way they present the other sets from the wave at the back of the instructions, it shows you what you can do if you combine some sets together.

Parts

Not many parts are included. But the notable ones include the TIE Fighter Cockpit window (doubling as The Emperor's view port) and Vader's chrome hilt. You even got a spare chrome hilt which Lego stopped doing shortly after these sets. 

Minifigures

While these minfigures have been seen many times now, at the time it was rare to get these figures in such a small set. The two are of course are Darth Vader and Emperor Palpantine. Firstly the Darth Vader figure. This is the 1999 to 2004 version. It comes with the old grey head with eye brows. The face is nicely detailed with the scars on the side of his head. It's a classics figure, how could you not love it? Next, the Emperor. This is the version with the yellow head which sorta feels odd since he had white/grey skin in the movie, of course this fixed with later additions. He comes with his cane which is a nice inclusion.

The build

The build is very, very simple. It can completed in about five minutes. 

The completed model

While it lacks a lot, it's still a charming set. Lego manage to convey the scene quite well. I like the control panels on the chair and it is able to turn too. And that's about it but for what's it worth, it's very nice!

Summary

Overall how could you not love this set? I remember how excited I was when I first got it. You get two figures which even now aren't seen that often in sets this cheap, in fact I don't they have again. It's a charming and classic set.

author: mrmitch
title: Darth Vader a must for any and every collection
review: I simply bought this set for the mini figures. I had to have Darth Vadar and Palpatine for my small Star Wars collection. I do like the window its cool the throne or chair is cool also. Don't own alot of the series but do enjoy this small set.

author: Leggodt94
title: "From Here, You Will Witness The Final Destruction Of The Alliance, And The End To Your Insignificant Rebellion." - Emperor Palpatine
review: You'll also witness Darth Vader throwing your old butt down the hole too, Palpatine. Oh! Hello there! I was just....hehehehe.....never mind! Anyways, so this set comes with cool Darth Sidious(with cane) and Vader minifigs plus palpatine's window and chair that spins. It's pretty cool mainly considering the price of the set, but this set is really not all that necessary considering that the new 10188 Death Star set comes with the emperor's entire throne room. Works great with Final Duel II set as well.

author: Pepper
title: cheap way to get the Emperor and Vader
review:
My mom bought me this set at K-Mart on sale a few years ago along with Jango Fett's Slave 1, Jedi defence 1, and Jedi duel. Well, onto the pros. and cons.

Pros.
cool minifigs (Emperor and Darth Vader)
lightaber
Emperor's throne
window

Cons.
no Royal Guards
no Sith lightning

The cons. are not that bad, so if you are a STAR WARS fan get it mostly for the minifigs.

author: Gus_263
title: Final Duel
review: This set is one of the small Star Wars sets released in 2002, in a size like the two Jedi Defense sets. This set is simple, not involves much building but still cool in the few building, the good color scheme and also the minifigures. The two minifigures included are Darth Vader and Darth Sidious. Darth Vader is simple but nicely designed, the miifigure have the helmet as head, but it still good due to the details, and also, Darth Vader have a red sith lightsaber and a cover. Darth Sidious is too simple, but still cool in the designs, the notable scared face, and also a little staff and a cover. The few building of the set is the throne, good builted altough small, combines some scenery, the wall that is on it back, and the window made with the TIE cockpit's front. The throne have a good size for the minifigure and the color scheme overall, is amazing. The playability is simple like the size, but this small can increase some other Star Wars sets, a cheap option to get more small scenery and two classic Star Wars minifigures.

author: jonbuddy
title: "*A/C comes on* Ah, man I'm right under the air vent! And the chair's bolted to the floor?!" - Emperor (from a Robot Chicken Star Wars sketch)
review:
I remember when all of the original classic SW sets first came out...getting Jabba's Palace and the add-ons...getting this and Final Duel II, of course, as well. Okay, nostalgia over.

Pros

  • Old Emperor
  • Old Darth Vader
  • Swivel Chair
  • Perfect when put with Final Duel II

Cons

  • Very simplistic
  • Have to get Final Duel II as well

So this set isn't the best on it's own, but oh well. It still provided the Emperor's chair & room for early Death Star mocs, but besides that is not a must-buy.

 

-jonbuddy

author: lego_here
title: Cheap way for figures
review:

author: ShatteredGnome
title: Destroy Him, Luke, It Is Your Destiny
review:
I got this set around the time I also got Final Duel II, about when it first came out. Looking back, this set was very unique and gives a lot for $6.99.

 

The Build and Playability:

Building this set is very easy, as you just have a small chair and window that go on a flat brick, basically. However, this small amount of pieces gives you a pretty nice looking product: a swiveling Emperor's chair. In addition, you get some nice rarer parts, like a TIE window and some special black pieces. But mainly, the minifigs are what make the set. Play is kind of limited if you don't have 7201, unless you want to just pit Vader against the Emperor.

 

Minifigures:

Vader is nothing special, and the Emperor is just your average one, not to mention both of these figures have been hugely outdated by flesh colors and new, more accurate prints, but the thing that rocks is the price. You get DARTH VADER AND THE EMPEROR for just 7 dollars. These figs may be outdated, but that was a good deal, way back then.

 

Pros:

-Vader and Palpatine cheap

-Cool looking chair

-Some nice parts

 

Cons:

-Play limited without 7201

 

Overall 9/10

author: Crt2
title: AWESOME!
review:
Story

Back in 2002, When KB Toys was Still around, I Was a Big Star wars Fan (I Hate Star Wars Now. :D). I Was Looking for Star wars Things when I Saw Final Duel II. My dad got it for me, And On the Back of the Bow, I Saw an Icon for FD I. We Looked and Looked Everywhere for It (Palpatine was My favorite Character), Then We Gave Up.......And My Dad Ordered it Online! I Can Still Remember Opening That UPS Box.................

  Review

I Praise Everything About This set, Palpatine, Vader, Chrome LS. It Even Includes a TIE Window! I Only Have 6 Star wars Sets (All Dissasembled), And This is By Far my Favorite.

 Pros

*Yellow Palpatine only in 2 Sets!

*Vader only in 3 Sets.

*Cool Printed Tiles on Chair.

*TIE Window.

*Chair Spins.

*Goes Great with FD II.

*Cheap for what you Get.

 Cons

*I Just Realized That This was Selling for $7! That's Pretty Expensive for 31 Parts! (Even Worse is the $20 Price on Bricklink.!)

 Overall

This Set Brings Back a lot of memories. if You Click The "Not Helpful" Button Below, I Don't Care. This set is perfect. 10/10

author: Odeinoichus
title: Good, Good, Heh, Heh, Heh.
review:
Set #7200 Final Duel I: What is this set? It is basically LEGO's answer to the clamoring for LEGO Emperor Palpatine and Darth Vader in an affordable set.

 

Much like Jedi Defense, also released in the same year, Final Duel I on it's own isn't 100% great, but it is a charming looking display piece, and it does offer up two rare Mini-Figures. Also this set was concieved of long before we ever got the Death Star, so really it is a bargain.

 

You get to build a little throne for the Emperor and the window behind him. It doesn't take long and probably would take less than five minutes to finish. But once it is built it gives you a lot of great potential for playing. As I said this set includes Yellow Faced Emperor Palpatine and Darth Vader. Both figures are rare in this price range to find and a welcome addition to any LEGO Mini-Figure collection.

 

Overall however I'd say if you already have a Vader and Palpatine from one of the larger sets then tracking this one down might not be altogether necessary. Unless you want a yellow faced Palpatine to stand amongst your LEGO City or regular Space Theme display. And of course to all LEGO Star Wars Completists it doesn't really matter what anybody says, they will buy every set available regardless, because they have that itch that just won't leave them alone. (I should know I am one.)

author: wander099
title: Emperor Palpatine and Darth Vader
review:
This set was released around the same time as the two Jedi Defence sets and the Final Duel II set.

Box/Instructions

The instructions are clear and simple, just like the sets I mentioned above.  I cannot recall what the box was like, I got this set when I was younger and I did not keep it.

Parts

The only part that could be considered special in this set is the window behind the swiveling throne.  It is the same as the cockpit on the TIE fighter.

Minifigures

This is where the value of the set really lies.  You get Darth Vader and Emperor Palpatine which were only available in much larger sets at the time.

The build

The build is really easy.  Not challenging at all.

The completed model

The completed model has only one feature, the chair can turn.  Other than that, without Final Duel II there isn't really much playability here.  If you have Final Duel II you can at least re-enact the battle between Luke, Vader, and Palpatine.

Summary

At the time of release, it was a good set.  There was no other way to re-enact this final battle for many people who didn't have the larger sets with these characters and there was no Death Star yet.  My rating reflects the situation in which the set was released and it was the only way I could get Vader, who I really wanted.

However, I think this set still has a lot of value today (just a little bit less because of the spectacular Death Star set).  While the new Darth Vader is available in the relatively inexpensive Darth Vader's TIE Fighter ($40 CDN), all the other versions of Palpatine are available only in expensive sets, especially the newest version which is available in only 2 sets, one of which is the Death Star.  A yellow skinned Palpatine may not be as good as the new one, but it is better than not having one at all.

author: thechabear
title: the empire strikes back in a mini set
review:
Hello everyone, it's time to do another review. This time it's a blast from da past. This set is a ok set and if you want to know why, read on and find out.

 

 

Box/Instructions

old sets (especially star wars) are very expensive to get with the box, even the small sets. I did not get the box but I did get the instructions. The instructions are unique to the old star wars sets and I like the format of them. On the back, it advertises the old lego star wars website and the 2002 star wars sets.

Parts

The parts that stood out to me were

the tie fighter window

the 2 printed tiles on the chair

and the base plate

 

Minifigures-2

DARTH VADER (2002): The darth vader figure is a common figure but comes in the expensive lego sets. Getting it for $6.00 is such a good deal. He has the original vader printing so not a lot of it, he also has his trademark cape, helmet, and lightsaber. Like all of the darth vader figures (not the 2014 and 2015 figures), he has black plain legs. Under his helmet is a scarred with no eyebrows Anakin skywalker\vader face. He weilds the chrome lightsaber.

DARTH SIDIOUS\THE EMPEROR (2002): What could get better then having darth vader in a set? Probably having the emperor in a cheap set. He has the same cape and legs as darth vader. His robes look like the luke old figure. He has the hood covering his face and he has a wrinkled old yellow face. His weapon is a cane.

 

The build

It didn't take me long at all. It took me around a minute.

 

The completed model

Not very detailed like the new versions of this set (final duel 2015 and death star). The emperor can look out his tie fighter window and sit in his chair. The chair does swivel so the emperor can look out the window or at darth vader. Very week in my opinion.

Overall opinion

I think this set is more like a battle pack like the other 3 (final duel 2, jedi duel 1 and 2). We get 2 awesome minifigures which are hard to get in cheap sets. I do like the throne and the window but i think they could have added more and made it a $15.00 set. I really like the minifigs but not the build. Be sure to check out my other reviews and i will see you all next time

author: Maltheus
title: "Good... gooooood..."
review:
This set features Emperor Palpatine's throne room from Return of the Jedi. I'm not quite sure when and where I got this set, but chances are it was a small extra-gift from my mother for my eleventh birthday.

Box/Instructions

It's a simple cardboard box, which, disappointingly, does not show any alternate builds on the back. Instead, we get the same picture from the front, only with a different background, along with two stills from the movie, showing Darth Vader and the Emperor, respectively. The back of the box also tells us to combine this set with 7201 in order to have Luke and Vader fight against each other.

The Instruction booklet is easy enough to follow and tells you everything you need to know. There's also a few pages worth of ads, showing you which other Star Wars sets there are to collect. Somewhat interestingly, the instructions tell you to put Vader's lightsaber in his left hand, despite him being right-handed in the movies.

Parts

Not much to say here, the set comes with a couple of black and grey bricks to build the Emperor's throne and the window through which he can look into the vastness of space. Nothing to spectacular here. I am at least impressed with how well the Tie-Fighter cockpit piece works as the throne room window. Also, in my set, one of the default SW control panel bricks for the throne is printed a lot darker than the other. Guess the darker one is a misprint.

Minifigures

Both Palpatine and Vader were pretty rare figures at the time, especially since you could only get them from buying some of the more expensive sets. I guess for people with less disposable income, this set was an easy way to get a Palpatine and Vader for their kids. I'm not sure why they gave the Emperor yellow skin, though, his skin looks to be of a greyish-white in the movies. Maybe they did this to differentiate him from Vader's grey head, but to me, it just looks kinda off and I remember actually switching their heads around as a child, because I was really disappointed with yellow skinned Palpatine.

The build

For a 30 pieces set, it's a pretty accurate representation of the throne room, I think. They captured the design of Palpatine's chair really well, right up to the little canopy on top. The whole set is fairly easy to build and it hardly takes more than two minutes to get it assembled.

I have a slight issue with Palpatine's throne, however, because he tends to get his cape bunched up when seated. I don't know if having him seated for longer periods of time makes his cape wrinkly, but it definitely does look pretty weird.

Playability

While the model itself offers no action features (apart from having the Emperor revolve in his chair), the fact that you get a Palpatine and a Vader figure makes for great playability. At least I as I child loved having Vader hoist the Emperor up and throwing him down an imaginary shaft to his death.

Overall Opinion

It's a nice little set and at least at the time was an easy way to get a hold of the two main villains of the original trilogy. For people who love Emperor Palpatine and Darth Vader like myself, this set is definitely pretty neat.

author: Max_Rebo
title: Final Duel 1
review:
Very little death star final duel set.
